description: Azure AD Identity Protection detected impossible travel for aisherlock@agentix.ad.bakerstreetlabs.io indicating credential compromise. Account authenticated from London (81.2.69.142) and Sydney (1.128.0.10) within 3.4 hours - requiring 4,975 km/h travel speed across 17,015 km distance (physically impossible). London session: Windows 10 laptop, Chrome browser, normal email/calendar access, registered corporate device LABS-WKS-221, successful MFA via Microsoft Authenticator. Sydney session: unregistered Android device (Samsung Galaxy), legacy auth protocol bypassing MFA (IMAP/POP3), immediate bulk OneDrive download (47 files, 127MB), suspicious Teams channel access. Sydney IP flagged in threat feeds for credential stuffing, shows VPN characteristics. Correlates with phishing site access (ebjv.com.au/filesharer) 4.4 hours prior, confirming credential theft vector. Risk score: Critical (98/100) - high confidence account compromise with active attacker usage.
user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) Chrome/131.0.0.0 Safari/537.36
location: London, United Kingdom â†’ Sydney, Australia
policy_description: Impossible travel detected: London to Sydney in 3.4 hours (17,015 km, requires 4,975 km/h speed) - indicates credential theft and attacker usage
policy_recommendation: IMMEDIATE ACTION REQUIRED: (1) Force password reset for aisherlock@agentix.ad.bakerstreetlabs.io immediately and block all active sessions, (2) Revoke all refresh tokens and OAuth grants for this account, (3) Disable legacy authentication protocols (IMAP/POP3/SMTP) for entire organization via Exchange Online protection policies to prevent MFA bypass, (4) Enable Azure AD Identity Protection automatic remediation for High-risk users (force password change + MFA re-registration), (5) Investigate data exfiltration: review OneDrive audit logs for 47 files downloaded from Sydney IP (1.128.0.10), analyze Microsoft Teams channel access logs for sensitive information exposure, check SharePoint access attempts, (6) Block attacker IP 1.128.0.10 at firewall and Azure AD level, hunt for similar authentication patterns from same IP across organization, (7) Notify user aisherlock of confirmed account compromise via phone call (do not use email - attacker has email access), instruct user to check personal accounts for credential reuse, (8) Conduct forensic analysis of LABS-WKS-221 workstation (user's London device) for persistent malware or keyloggers that could lead to re-compromise, (9) Review conditional access policies: enforce MFA for all authentication protocols including legacy auth, implement continuous access evaluation (CAE) to revoke access in real-time, enable device compliance checks, (10) Deploy security awareness training organization-wide emphasizing phishing recognition and immediate incident reporting, (11) Consider implementing passwordless authentication (FIDO2 hardware keys, Windows Hello for Business) to eliminate password phishing attacks entirely, (12) Enable Azure AD Identity Protection risk-based conditional access policies blocking High-risk sign-ins automatically
